Cho!  Dang, has been a staple Korean restaurant for some time for many Chandler folks.  I've never lived in Chandler, but I never mind making my journey south to come here.  I generally wait till the weather gets a little cooler before coming to Chodangs because I always order their Tofu Soup.  

They used to serve their rice in a stone bowl, but not particularly sure why they stopped.  Probably because some idiot kept burning themselves (thanks for ruining it for all of us!)  Anyways, I totally recommend this traditional dish if you haven't tried it yet!  Especially, on a "cold winter" day in the valley.  I would go with the #2 which has oysters, shrimp, and beef all in one.  Plus, I recommend including the egg when they as if you want them to add it for you!  Nice hot broth cooking the egg with a bowl of steaming white rice!  Perfect for any winters day!  It would kick any cold out of the way!

In the end, Chodangs great if you can handle some spice and pungent smell of Korean food.  I would consider this place one of the best in town! - Enjoy!

This place gets busy!

Six of us came here for weekend lunch around 11:30am and we took the last large table and only two more small tables left.  Service was bit slow but I wasn't expecting much anyway.

As soon as you walk in, you will smell nice Korean food.  Typical Korean food smell. Gimpo airport used to have this smell too. (before Incheon opened).  You know you just landed in Korea with this smell.  I was hungry for some good kimuchi and korean food as soon as I walked in.

They served six small side dishes to start. Korean seaweed, two types of kimuchi, potato salad (with apple), bean sprout salad, and one more something I couldn't tell what it was.  Kimuchi had nice flavor, I wish it was spicier but they have good nice taste. All other small side dishes were very good and authentic.

We shared steamed dumping, bulgogi, didimbap.  Some of the reviewers suggested Soondubu jjigae (soft tofu soup) but the day we visited was hot outside and didn't feel like hot soup.  As I enjoyed my lunch here, I would like to come back to try their soondobu.  The place I used to enjoy in North Scottsdale changed something and it doesn't taste the same anymore, so this will be good place to try. 

They have sign in English and Korean, yes, this means they have customers speak/read Korean.

probably the best soondubu in phoenix... although it could use a little more tofu... otherwise, it's nice and spicy!!! although i did order hot... and i usually order the medium. 
the bf really enjoyed his dolsot bibimbap... these people don't skimp on quality ingredients! 
and the banchan was for the most part, quite enjoyable - tasty seaweed both dry and wet, apple salad, radish/cucumber kimchi... and some over salted bean sprouts and not so great cabbage kimchi. 
but overall... the service was fantastic, the food tasted wonderful, it was rather affordable.... i'd recommend stopping for the lunch specials (12-3 i believe)
if only it wasn't on the opposite side of the valley....

First of all, can I just say that the place is outstandingly clean. The service is good. The food came fast. Serving is big, totally for sharing (for 2). So 4 stars for that. Totally a little gem on Arizona Ave. The only tiny thing is the food that I ordered was lacking just a tad bit of flavor. But all in all, of course I'll come back. :)

This place was pretty good. Visiting from Chicago where Korean restaurants are bountiful, Chodang held it's own.  Owners were super friendly, place was very clean and the staff was just helpful and accommodating, something I'm not used to in Korean places LOL.  My brother and I had the yukgaejang with noodles, something different neither of us had, instead of having it with traditional white rice, we opted for noodles in the soup.  The bf had the basic dol sot bibimbop, which was just fine, can't really mess up that dish.  All dishes were super flavorful, only thing were the banchan, a bit smaller than what I'm used to as far as assortment and just sheer quantity, but that didn't really break my visit.

My absolute favorite Korean in the valley. Been constantly disappointed in my search for authentic Korean since I moved here, and as soon as I had my first bite here- I knew I would be a regular. 
The staff is so nice, the food is authentic and always on point, and there's no going wrong with the menu.

First off, I love Korean food and have had a lot of it especially since I lived near Koreatown in LA for a while.  Ever since moving to Mesa, I have looked for a Korean place that resembles what I had in LA and Chodang is it! It's not everything you would find in Koreatown, but the soondubu is really good along with the rest of the menu items.  I typically order the spicy pork bulgogi (#23), which I love, and the seafood soondubu (#1).  I've also had the duk mandoo-guk (#54), a dumpling and rice cake soup, also very delicious and a very big portion, as is the yook gaejang mandoo (#42) a spicy red soup with beef and clear noodles.  So far I haven't had a single dish that I haven't liked and have even brought Korean friends from out of town that have complimented the place.  Service is always excellent and fast, and the apple salad that comes as the japchae is amazing!

I am by no means a Korean food connoisseur.  In fact, I can probably count the number of authentic Korean meals I've had on my fingers... and maybe a few toes.

Chodang was such a fun experience.  I enjoyed the food and the company.  After all, I was there with a group of yelpers!  I thought the service was decent and so was the atmosphere... gotta love the music they play!  The portions are large and the prices are affordable, but nothing about my experience blew me away.  

I did appreciate that upon my request, the put a fried egg on my bi bim bop.  (I highly recommend doing this!)  I shared the BBB and a jop chi noodle dish with my husband... we also tried some of the meat dishes and ribs, and of course we chowed on the traditional Korean side dishes such as kim chi, bean sprouts, seaweed, etc...  We left with full bellies and leftovers, which was great.

But would I drive 30 minutes out of my way to return?  I'm not sure... However, if you are in the Chandler area and craving Korean, stop by Chodang and enjoy!

Chodang...I've been to Chodang several times.  All my experiences here are great.  I usually get the Bugolgi which is very similar to their teriyaki beef.  All their side dishes are always great which usually comes with some dried seaweed, fresh seaweed, radish kimchi, cabbage kimchi, sweet apples, and bean sprouts.  Awesome place if you like Korean Food!  This place is also friendly and is very neat and clean.   Always come here with the co-workers.
Delicious and authentic... We had a great lunch though came out like $20 per person. 4 soups, jap chae, bulgogi and kalbi.

Chodang is my favorite Korean Restaurant in Arizona. Whether you are in the mood for soup, BBQ, noodles, dumplings or other Korean dishes, they always deliver with the quality of their food. Starting off with the variety of Kimchi that is served to every table. Each different type of kimchi are very delicious but my favorites are the bean sprout kimchi and the curried potatos. My go to for the an Entree is the Dumpling Tofu Soup. You have the option of adding an egg when they bring it to the table. If you want it they crack the egg into your boiling soup with you can stir in or let cook in one part of your soup. We shared the Beef Bulgogi and Fried Dumplings which were both amazing. This is definitely a place I will be coming back to!

Came here with family out of town (Tustin, CA and Houston, TX) and we were impressed with the korean food here.  The Galbi and Bulgogi was delicious (tender and juicy) along with the a generous portion of the spicy squid.  Price is comparable and usual like other korean restaurants.  The only thing maybe have more of a variety of banchan (two of them were seaweed wrap).

Told my husband to pick a place to eat and he chose this place. Upon arrival I thought it looked pretty ghetto but when I walked into the restaurant it smelled really good! The whole environment itself was fairly clean so I liked that. I order a mushroom tofu soup and a galbi lunch special. The tofu soup was super flavorful with the perfect touch of spice (I ordered spicy). The color of the galbi wasn't as dark as I'm used to but it tastes good too. Only thing I was t impressed was the little appetizer dishes they gave us. The kimchi didn't taste as good. But I really like the fact that they had seaweed papers to much on! That's a little different than other Korean appetizer dishes. I'll definitely come back!

This place is amazing. Way cheaper than Korean barbecue and you will have a fantastic experience. The appetizers are fantastic, the soup is fantastic, and all the meat tastes premium and it wont run you over 20 dollars.

I wanted my friend who lives in the area to try some bulgogi but this place was very disappointing!  The meat was all fatty and tasted like it was marinated for 5 minutes instead of overnight. Definitely not like the Korean places we have in San Diego!  

The service is great, but the food sucks. If you've ever been to a Korean bbq restaurant, where you grill at your own table, you're going to be very disappointed with this place!

When it's cold, my family come here almost every week for the tofu soup. The galbi is my favorite dish. Service is good and friendly. Also, price is very reasonable.

We checked out a few Korean restaurants around Chandler, Mesa, Tempe area but this is my go-to place so far.

Pretty good korean food overall.  They don't let you cook at your own table, but the barbecue is good quality.  There are limited items though- only a bugolgi, kalbi, spicy chicken, and spicy pork.  No sam gyup sal with the sesame/salt dressing which is a little disappointing because that's our favorite.  The tofu soup is probably the best thing they have here- be careful that you don't order it too spicy (most places we order "hot" and here we order "medium" because the "hot" is too much heat for us to really enjoy it).

They're great with kids- our toddler spills stuff everywhere and they are always quick/gracious to help us clean things up.

Fast service, clean restaurant.  Wish they expanded the menu a little bit!

Sigh, I had really high expectations coming into this place. 
Korean bbq is one of my favorite dinner adventures and I've been spoiled growing up close to Koreatown in Los Angeles. 

The banchans are adequate, nothing spectacular but they definitely calibrated and increased the prices of their entrees so take advantage of the refills. 

You don't get to grill your own meats, which eliminates half the fun of the KBBQ experience. 

We ordered a galbi, bulgogi, and kimchi tofu soup. The bulgogi was missing the sweet marinated flavor that I was looking for, and although the meat was tender, it was a bit over-cooked. The galbi was a lot better in comparison, but again, nothing special. The tofu soup was probably the best part of the meal, but not even as good as BCD.
It's an Asian restaurant, so the service will be lacking...but really I'm disappointed in making such a far trek and don't see myself coming back
Awesome Korean! Tofu Soups are the best! Bulgogi is amazing. Highly recommended

I don't remember how long it's been since we first started coming here but it's def been one of my favorites here in the desert! As hot as the summers are here, it almost seems doggone wrong to be eating super spicy foods but if that's a sin, then so be it! During the colder months, these warm and spicy dishes just make you feel nice and warm like a hug from the inside out!

My all time favorite here is the mushroom tofu soup medium hot spicy with the egg drop together with the dak bul gogi and the yummy pan chan and of course the fresh hot fluffy rice! When there are more in our dining party, I also like to indulge in the acorn noodles, chap jae, kalbi and or bul gogi!!!

Lunches here are a nice portion and the dinners are quite generously portioned too! The kim chee is just spicy enough for those with slightly spicy palates but not too overwhelming for those with more sensitive tastes!

The staff are all quite friendly and extremely attentive to all of your needs! Service is especially fast and the restaurant is always clean! I hope this family friendly business will be around for many years to come!!!
Loved the kim chi.  The beef and pork was excellent. The place is a bit of a whole on the outside but clean on the inside.
Food was yummy. Big portion for lunch special. The pork is a bit too spicy but the beef is really good!!

My partner gives me hell for loving Korean Dramas, and thought I was nuts that I wanted to try to food based on something I've seen on television, but he decided to give it a shot with me, after several months of convincing.  
One word: Love!
The food at Chodang is consistently flavorful and delicious.  
The partner can't get enough of the spicy bbq pork, he even asks for extra sauce on the side, though upon this last trip it proved to be just a tad too spicy for him with the addition.
My favorite part of the dishes at Chodang, is the balance of flavors.  Nothing I've had there has just been one note, even the side dishes (excluding the marinated seaweed). Each dish covers at least three flavor profiles and if you want more, add a bit of kimchi, bean sprouts or another side dish to get a richer experience.
My favorite so far has been the 74 (I don't want to butcher the spelling of the dish).  The combination of the octopus, kimchi and bulgogi is wonderful.  
When I'm sick, the tofu soups, especially the seafood tofu soup, is how I find comfort, plus the spiciness is great for the sinuses. (Make sure to get it with an egg table side.)
Chodang also introduced me to the JPop, and I have to say it's now a staple whenever I have a meal there. 
The service is great too! They aren't overbearing, and they do not provide the snobby kind of Asian service.  I've been to many Asian run restaurants where if you don't look like you are from their country they will give you a generic menu.  Chodang serves everyone equally.
Which Asian restaurant doesn't serve hot tea?  Weird!  Food was average.  Small portion.  But the 6 side dishes were good.  It made it up for the not so generous entree dishes.
It's really really good! I had the kimchi soup, my husband had rice. Finally found somewhere having good Korean! Most people eating here are Korean. Good sign.

My great-grandmother was Korean and my grandmother still passes on her cooking and recipes.  I'd have to say this place is very yummy and authentic.  I love their Bulgogi beef and chicken, the flavor is spicy and smoky.  My favorite item is the Spicy Tofu Soup - it comes in a huge bowl, steaming hot, spicy and they crack an egg in it and it's served with rice.  Amazing for the cooler fall and winter months!  Restaurant is always very clean as well.
This is probably the best Korean food in the area- not as good as SoCal or my Korean Aunt- but whenever we get a craving for Korean we head to Chodang!

I finally got my korean tofu soup (sundubu) cravings satisfied today! I came here after church with a group of friends and we were seated quickly. It did start getting busy around 12:45 though. The waiter was very friendly and got all of our orders right! He even repeated what we ordered to make sure he got all the spicy levels down on each dish.

They gave each of our 2 tables 5 small dishes (banchan) with potatoes, bean sprouts, crispy seaweed, kimchi, and apple slices. The potato side/small dish was my favorite. I enjoyed the seafood sundubu (tofu soup) I ordered but it wasn't quite as flavorful as some other sundubu I've tried elsewhere; it might've been because I ordered the "Light" spicy level. My sister ordered a kimchi and pork sundubu in "Hot" spicy level and it was a lot more flavorful than mine. Still, I liked the clams and shrimp in my tofu soup and the steaming bowl of hot rice that accompanied it. Most of my other friends got sundubu as well. We all wanted a raw egg placed in our sundubu which the waiter added for free for us. If you push the egg to the bottom of your bowl and cover it with steaming tofu, the soup ends up poaching the egg perfectly.

They made it easy to pay separately among the 7 people there by just having us all stop by the cash register on our way out so that they could charge each amount on our individual credit cards, which I appreciated because it isn't always easy to eat together in large groups. 
The only thing was that service did get a little slower towards the end of the meal and we waited awhile for our check because the restaurant was filling up. 
Good place for Korean food!

I didn't know anything about Korean food before first visiting Chodang Tofu & BBQ, but the food here inspired me to start making kimchi and grilling bulgogi at home. My wife loves tofu, so she gets a different type of tofu soup each time we go. The grilled dishes and the hot stone-bowl rice/egg dish (bibimbap) come from the kitchen sizzling violently, so there's a bit of theater when these dishes are served. 

We love the little appetizers, like kimchi and marinated bean sprouts, that accompany the meal. You get the full set of six even if you just order a lunch bowl, and it's more food than I can finish.

The atmosphere is surprisingly pleasant inside given the seedy nature of the exterior and neighborhood (I always wonder why they picked that location; I get nervous leaving my car in back). The interior is clean and orderly with a spare, Asian look that's very appealing. It's easy to imagine you're in a peaceful little family restaurant in Seoul, never mind the potential for gun violence outside.

This is a great place for lunch and groups, just be aware that they are closed on Tuesdays (I learned that lesson the hard way and ended up consoling myself at Elmer's Tacos). Eating here is a must if you live around Chandler and like to try new things (assuming you're not Korean, in which case, try Elmer's).
My favorite Korean restaurant in town! They make good authentic Korean food in AZ. Food is really good and server is good!

We tried this place a few months ago and the food was excellent!  The service was not all that impressive.  I would describe the service as clinical if that makes sense.  The atmosphere was very casual with music playing a little on the loud side. I can't remember what we had other than the short ribs, but all of our food was terrific!  The food was definitely five star food, but they can improve on ambience, service, and also food presentation.

Chodang is so good! 

Kimchi Tofu Soup and Spicy Pork are AMAZING!!!

This is a must stop for me when I am in Arizona. Everything about this place is awesome. You can't anymore Korean than this. I get my favorite, Kalbi and bulgogi. Definitely stop by for lunch or dinner, you won't regret it!

Absolutely loved it! Which is surprising because nothing can compare to SoCal kbbq, but this will keep me happy until the next time I can take a trip next door to LA. 

Service was great and food was brought out quickly! Ban chan was delicious. They were quick to refill them as well. Menu is simple enough and have amazing bbq lunch specials. Bulgogi is marinated well and the Dwaeji bulgogi has just the right kick! Will definitely be back to try out the rest of the menu!

I've dined in and grabbed takeout several times. Food quality is superb as is the service. Restaurant is clean and portions are generous. Price is a little steep but I don't mind paying for great food. I'm giving 4 stars as they lack creativity with side dishes, it's always the same ones. Whereas other Korean restaurants I've tried have different offerings. I guess perhaps they may be sticking to what they do well. I'll be back.

One of my coworkers recommend me this place, and I'm glad he did it! Honestly I saw this restaurant many times, but the fact that in the name there is "tofu" I was a little afraid because I'm not a huge fan. But it was stupid of me because this place is great! I had the dumplings and they were excellent! And my family had other dishes that were all very tasty!
Must go. I loved their cold noodles! The best I have had in the US. Tofu soup was just right ! We had our dose of good Korean food and satisfied. Will come back for sure. Service is also good.

Food here not as good 
I don't like the fact they don't have the traditional kimchi made of cabbage ( they replaced w strips of daikon pickle) the cheapest stuffs ever and no fish cake ! A no no !!!
Ordered a seafood noddle bowl $12.99 but the Seafood are tiny junks from the mixed seafood bag sold at the supermarket $2.99 . Their tofu soup is tasteless 
Never return

I went here for dinner... wasn't too impressed. The service was horrible, it took 10 minutes just for us to get water.. and for being a Korean restaurant, they don't even have barley tea..which woahhh..whattt...pretty sure a Korean restaurant should have that? Anyways.. the food wasn't even that great, I know so many people who love this place..but come on, really? Hidori tops this place by a long shot..even Takamatsu. The sides they provided weren't even that fresh, perhaps I came in on an off day....what even pisses me off more is that a server blatantly ignored a husband and his wife that was waiting for 15 minutes for a server (okay seriously, that is really REALLY rude, especially when you look at them and roll your eyes..whoever you are nameless server). 

Either way, I was very disappointed in this place, I will never come back here again.

I can't say that I'm a Korean food expert, but every time I've come to chodang I've had such a great experience! The portions are really big and I almost always have to take leftovers home. I also find that the staff is really friendly and attentive to what you need which I really like especially at Asian owned restaurants. 

The only downfall is that right off the bat there aren't that many non-meat options, but I believe you can ask to make certain dished vegetarian! To me that isn't much of an issue, but to people with a strict diet that may hinder them a bit. 

The interior is nice so no complaints there! Overall a really quality Korean restaurant (it's my boyfriends fave place) and I never have anything bad to say after eating here!

This place has been open fro awhile now and I finally got to try it out. I was in the area with a friend of mine who constantly talked about how breat this places side dishes were. 

When we pulled up I was surprised to see the exterior of the building. Not so appealing from the outside, neither was the area it is in. The inside was much better but nothing like some of the places in LA this restaurant is based off of. 

The waitress that day seemed a gloomy and unwelcoming with her blank expressions and straight to the point service. I would have enjoyed the service a bit more if she was a bit more  enthusiastic. It wasn't till the end of our meal when we engaged conversation with her that she cracked a smile. 

We ordered the tofu stew, since this is their specialty. I got the kimchee beef and my friend got the mushroom and beef. I like that they have the stone pots for the rice since no one else here in AZ does it. The rice came out a bit on the wet side but I was so hungry at this point it didn't matter. The sides that were presented to us was not very exciting. I don't know what all the hype was about the sides, it was just like any other place but a lot less. We only got 4 sides and one of them being roasted seaweed. Come on now, anyone can cut that up and serve it, I want something that I can't do at home. The stew was ok at best and did have a good amount of meat which is good. 

All in all the service was ok, could have been better if my water was ever refilled. The food was ok nothing too exciting. A good place to go if you live in the area but like most of us who do not, not worth the drive. Possibly a harsh review since there are only a few Korean places in town but wouldn't you think since there are only a handful here and for some reason they all do tofu stew and a specialty that one would get it right. or at least enough for AZ but not this one to say the least.

Went with friends. Saw lots, tasted lots. I was sad to be disappointed. The seafood tofu soup was good, per a nearby taster. Short ribs were stringy. My bulgogi was too mushy, almost stewed, but tasted okay. The condiments were nice, tried em all no complaints. Dumplings were dry, overcooked with little stuffing. Bim Bam Bop went over big as did the soups. I like lettuce with my bulgogi, none to be seen, Service was bad, missed orders, etc. So, I guess, SOUP FOR YOU! Skip the rest. I like others better....
WHAT THE HELL?? We're regulars no more after our last visit.  Thoroughly ignored by the wait staff and nary an apology.  We will not go back!

Chodang, my favorite Korean place in greater phoenix area. 

Definitely not the world. When i am craving korean food this is my place of preference. Dolsot Bibimbap is good here. They don't skimp on their food.

The spiciness is on the lower end of my spice preference. Their hot is under the level of a jalapeno (in my opinion). This IS nice though because you are eating out of joy, not pain of spice. 

Anyways soondubu (i spelled that wrong i am sure) is good...

again i am saying not the best ever, just my favorite in the greater phoenix area.

Chodang is my absolute favorite place to get Korean food in the Phoenix area! All of their dishes from their banchan (side dishes) to their stews to their entrees are delicious and authentic. Their portions are also huge. I usually get the soondubu jjigae (tofu soup) and it's always really flavorful. Their hot stone bibimbap and daeji bulgogi are also really good if you're looking for a rice dish instead.

Service here is usually on top of things, helpful, and friendly. They also are really quick to refill water and side dishes if needed. 

Overall Chodang is my favorite Korean restaurant in the area. Definitely worth the visit if you're looking for authentic Korean food!

The tofu soup Is amazing. I also like the bulgogi, short ribs, and dumplings. Of the side dishes I really like their kimchi and the radish. Service is usually good. Reasonably priced though I wish they would do more appetizers or half orders of dumplings, I would order more stuff if I didn't have to get a whole other meal. Also note that they are closed 3 to 5 pm.

Ive visited this place many times over the years.
Here are my findings.

Pro: 
1. The decor is clean and very vibrant which is rare to find in Korean restaurant
2. Very well organized.

Cons:
1. Because the size of the restaurant, when its busy its crowded and the servers get overwhelmed.
2. Mixed up orders many times.
3. Banchan is the same every time.

Chodang is my favorite Korean restaurant in town. Their side dishes never disappoint. Especially their kimchi! I always get the bibim pap. My boys usually get a version of the Pul cogi! The food is authentic!

We took my older daughter, who is very much into Korean culture including kpop, here for a birthday lunch.   I was a little nervous as my only other experience with korean food involved super spicy jellyfish chunks.   But I was game to try again! 

OMG, it was amazing.   The food was fantastic.   We shared everything so that we could try different things.   Had the dumpling tofu soup with egg - phenomenal!  Can't wait to try the seafood soup next time.   The Korean spice BBQ pork was awesome and absolutely the best thing we tried.   We had a clear noodle dish,  similar to a stir fry which was good.  The fried dumplings were yummy as well.   

Service was great.   Food came out fast.   And they didn't mind helping us out with some suggestions as we are newbies.

I thought the ambiance was nice although the 80's music was a little odd, but enjoyable.

I just moved back from living in Asia for 5 years.  It's really difficult to find authentic and awesome Korean food. Chodang hits the mark!! It's fantastic!  
Order the spicy kimchi tofu soup over white rice. Kimchi Chi-ge mmmmmm!!! :)

I love Cho Dang and have had a good meal every time I have been there.  The first time we were there the server spoke perfect english (not always a guarantee here) and was able to explain to us what was popular and some of her favorites.  If we didn't have this help we may not have had as good of an experience.  With this in mind, let me suggest a first time meal for those that want to try this place out.  I go with my girlfriend and we usually get 2 meals and split them.  Order 1 tofu soup (dumpling and mushroom are our favorites) and order the Beef Bulgogi (Korean BBQ).  They will ask if you want an egg in your soup, go for it!  Rice made in a stone bowl comes with soup and regular rice comes with the Bulgogi.  The sides that come with it are great too.  You do not get to choose, they come with the meal so don't review the place and complain about not having a choice.  They give you 6 and they will fill them up if you need more.  They are very fresh too.

If you enjoy the first meal and want to go back I suggest always ordering one new item and one you know is good.  That way you can experiment but not ruin the experience with 2 new dishes you may not enjoy.  There are a few soup-type dishes I really enjoy as well as a dumpling dish.  The staff is friendly, attentive and if they aren't there is a button at the table to summon them!  

I see what I assume are Koreans there all the time and we are often the only ones that aren't.  We are kind of regulars and they know of us as the ones who love the seaweed.  By seaweed I mean the side that is wet and in a mild vinegar-y liquid.  I order extra when I get take-out because it is so yummy.  Sometimes they make a sesame flavored seaweed for the side that isn't as tasty.

Either way, I have been here no less than 30 times and I enjoy myself every time.  I leave satisfied, stuffed, and with a healthy portion of leftovers.  And for how much?  Usually in the $20-30 range for 2 meals, 2 iced teas, and the included sides.  

From the location and the outside it isn't anything special.  But it is a nice little oasis in the middle of El Chandlero.

After some horrible experiences at Hodori, I was very relieved to find this place to satisfy my korean cravings. I didn't get the chance to learn all of my mother's recipes before she passed away, but Chodang's delicious dishes always bring me comfort by reminding me of her cooking. I try to come here as often as I can.

Very good Authentic Korean BBQ.  I have tried the beef, short ribs and the spicy pork and it all was amazing.  The soup is great as well.  Fast service and sizzling hot food to the table.  I highly recommend this to all!

Way better than I expected!

I had Korean once before Chodang at another establishment about a year ago, and it was sub-par which I chalked up to the fact that Phoenix probably didn't have a big Korean population compared to some other parts of the US. Going into Chodang, I didn't have super high expectations but it far exceeded what I had imagined. The store itself is cozy and there's plenty of parking in the back. 

We ordered the seafood soft tofu stew, bulgogi (spicy marinated pork), and dolsot bibimbap (stone bowl bibimbap) which was very, very filling and all were super delicious. They gave us the side dishes when the food came which didn't take too long. The service was very nice; water was refilled in a timely manner as were side dishes. I'm always happy when I go to a Korean place, and they don't treat me like the foreigner that I am. It was quite expensive, though. $50 for the two of us. Regardless, would definitely return.

Chodang
501 N. Arizona Avenue
Chandler, AZ  85225



Companion and I have enjoyed Korean food in several venues, and this is the latest one. We arrive at 5:30 on a Saturday evening. The place was mildly busy. By the time we left however, every table was taken.

We were two of the only 3 Caucasians in the restaurant, which is usually a good sign. We were seated quickly, and sat for a while. We finally received menus, but no one took our drink orders.

Companion ordered Dol Sot Bibim Bap ($10.50). This is a dish that is served in a very hot stone bowl. It has assorted veggies over rice along with pieces of beef. A squeeze bottle of red pepper paste is served on the side for you to mix in as you like it. One of the highlights of Bibim Bap is the rice that gets caramelized by it's contact with the hot bowl. Companion pronounced the dish up to her standards and meeting all her expectations. Unfortunately, no on ever asked companion if she wanted anything to drink with her meal. She finally stopped a waitress and asked for a glass of water.

I ordered the Dak Bulgogi ($13.95) which is marinated pieces of (usually) dark meat chicken, sauteed in a sauce and served over slivered onions. The portion size was big enough for any eater, but I felt the sauce was a bit on the sweet side. Having eaten eaten this dish many times in various places, I was pretty sure that it should not have been as sweet as it was. I too, had to stop a waitress to ask for a soft drink. Another problem which I had with my dish is that part of a chore girl scrubbing pad was mixed in with my food! When I brought it to the attention of one of the waitresses, she immediately took it to the kitchen and offered to replace my dish. 

On the positive side, the Banchan (side dishes) were excellent, especially the nori seasoned with salt, and the bean sprouts marinated in sesame. Perhaps the most unusual was the ultra thin sliced apple with cucumber and onion mixed with what seemed to be mayonnaise. Not something I've eaten before, but not bad either. Their Kimchi was very good, and thankfully had been cut into smaller sized pieces which many placed fail to do. 

Other dishes available include Bulgogi (Korean BBQ Beef - $14.95), Assorted Tofu Soups ($9.75) and Jap-Chae (Rice noodles with Beef and Rice ($14.95). Strangely, Galbi (Marinated Short Ribs) which are a staple of Korean eating, are only available at lunch time.

Sanitation seemed good with the exception of the pieces of scrubbing pad in my main course.

Had the service been better, I might have opted to give them 4 stars, but a lot of the meal ambiance involves service, and it was sorely lacking this night.

Been here a couple of times but since I am in the Yelping mode, I had to get it off my chest.

Like I said in another Yelp for a Korean restaurant, I love Korean food.  My in-laws love this place plus they live down the street so we meet them here for dinner every now and then.

We usually order the same here, bulgogi, chap chae, and seafood pancake.  Sometimes we will order the spicy tofu soup and the bimbim bap.  Oh yeah, the kids order the pork cutlet cause they don't like the other stuff.  The sides are very good and would be rated higher if I was just rating the sides.

The place is clean but kind of small.  Service is alright at times but sometimes we have to get up to find a server.  I think it is over priced for the amount of food we get but I think all Korean places seem pricey.

This place is alright but I am only go here if the in-laws want to meet up.
Awesome customer service...I am a deliverer for Door Dash and would HIGHLY recommend this restaurant to anyone!

One of the better Korean food places in phx. Their tofu soup is on par with what tofu soup tastes like in California, only pricier in phx. Their meats are also on par with what you would find in above average places in Cali too. So if you like Korean food and you're nearby, give them a try.

DELICIOUS!! Don't run away from the exterior...its rather nice inside!

Price:
Its reasonable price for the amount of food that is given. If it was cheaper that would make my day! They offer a cheaper menu for lunch but of course the amount of food is lessen too.

Service:
The service is so so, nothing amazing. I would say average, they take your order, serve, drop your check. The usual.

Food:
The food is absolutely amazing. Bulgogi and Galbi are perfectly seasoned and the complimentary sides are a nice. We shared a piping hot, clam tofu soup along with the two dishes for all four and left satisfied. One dish would be good for sharing! 

I would recommend this place to everyone, including families with kids. Best korean restaurants in AZ so far for me.

Decent korean food for the area.
Soondobu  was decent, the side dishes that they gave were decent.
They have horrible hours of operation (but looks like business is good enough during those hours), and they are a bit over priced ($17 for hwaemool pajun?!?! Thats the seafood pancake).

The first tofu house I found in AZ! I don't know if they are affiliated to the cho-dang in Los Angeles but that was the only one I'd go to in Cerritos when I lived in LA. If you are a tofu soup lover than you must go here! They have the best soup and selection for soft tofu soup. I am a creature of habit and always get the kimchi tofu soup with beef. My husband got kalbi and it was pretty good too!

Yelp!!! This is my favorite place for korean food. Their service is okay, but their food is really good. The tofu soup and Galbi are really good. 
You can save a couple buck by coming at lunch to get the lunch special.

Tried a few more dishes, and was most impressed with the tofu soup which spicy, flavorful, and filled with a good amount of meat and tofu.  The bbq items were all too sweet (kalbi and beef bulgolgi), while the jap chae was decent and came in a gigantic bowl for everyone to share.
Good food and fast service! I would recommend one of the tofu soups, definitely hit the spot!
Very delicious Korean bbq!!! Tried the marinated bbq beef bulgogi--size is very filling and super tasty! I will def be going back for some more!

Chodang is my favorite place in the Valley for tofu soup. I order some variation every time I come here. The soup is flavorful with a generous amount of tofu, meats, seafood, etc. The banchan are also very good; the potato, apple, bean sprouts, and Kimchi are delicious. 

Dishes such as galbi and bulgogi are delicious, but the portions are a bit small for the price. Service is friendly and you usually don't have to wait long to receive food.

I love their tofu soup. The broth is flavorful and I think it is the best of any Korean place in the valley. Their bbq is always good. We usually like to get the spicy chicken or kalbi. Their side dishes are good too. It is a well run restaurant since their food quality and service is pretty consistent.

According to the soya.be website the earliest recorded reference to Tofu is in the poem Ode to Tofu, written at the end of the 15th century, in 1500 AD. Well, a bit over 500 years later, I have to say that my experience at Chodang makes me also want to wax eloquent on the joys of solidified bean curd, or what we know as the humble tofu.

I've had Tofu before, and tofu in miso soup but never Korean style Miso soup. I'd given blood and decided I needed something to invigorate my depleted blood supply and some Kim-Chee soup with beef seemed just the ticket. The nice thing about Chodang, it follows the Korean meal practice of setting out a number of small savory dishes, often with a mix of pickled vegies, and then bringing out the main course, which in this case was a bubbling hot bowl of soup, which the wait person will happily crack a raw egg into, which I recommend, and a side of rice. 

I ordered the soup a four on a  four out of five scale as my one time having truly Thai hot Thai food has made me wary of going for the top of the scale the first time in a restaurant. In  this case, if you like spicy, for four a 5 out of 5 level as the 4 out of 5 didn't seem all that spicey. However, I did love the tofu in the soup, they seemed to use a soft tofu which sort of breaks off in ragged chunks and was wonderful in the soup which was thick with kim-chee and had a number of thin slices of beef included. 

I do hope to come back again and follow the advice of Lester C (excellent reviewer of all things Asian, he has never steered my wrong so a shout out to my fellow elite Yelper) and try the Korean BBQ. I saw a plate of Korean short rips go by and they ,looked, as they say in Hawaii, Ono! It is a bit out of the way from where I live but only a few miles from the United Blood bank in Chandler so go do some good, give some blood and then reward yourself with a visit to this lovely Korean restaurant.

P.S. - only weird thing, they serve the hot tea, which is more like warm team, in a large, plastic water glass, blah. Spif it up a bit Chodang and provide a teapot and a small cup for green tea. It won't cost much and adds to the experience.:-)

Stopped by here for dinner one night and had a pretty good experience. Korean food can be tricky... depending on the area you're in they may or may not serve some more esoteric (and delicious) dishes- some of which are must-haves for me to be able to really enjoy a good Korean meal. Sikhye being one of them (a rice dessert drink)- for some reason a Korean meal just doesn't seem to end right for me without it. I love Korean fish dishes, and hwe dup bap is another go-to for me. Their selections of banchan were good, and fairly typical for a good Korean resaurant. We had bi bim bap and another hot stone-pot dish which I can't really recall, as well as some steamed dumplings. Everything was fine- nothing to rave about, but nothing to complain about either. 

I really hate to be one of those "I've had better" snobs, but I have. However, for someone who was just curious about Korean food and wanted to try something which would serve as a good introduction, you could do a lot worse than Chodang.
Korean short ribs, unbelievable tofu soups. First rate Korean food. A must try.

First time I had Korean food. It was definitely different for me. My fiancé has has korean in south korea and said this food was almost identical to flavor. Since it was my first time is was something new that will grow on me. Therefore, the portion size of the entrées were massive! My rice bowl could have fed two people. I was disappointed that my rice bowl was sizzling hot still 30 minutes after they served me and it was hard to eat. It was delicious flavors and the paste gave it a great kick. Definitely would recommend this location for korean. Very good food, awesome service and large portions.
My first time in an authentic Korean restaurant. Food was excellent with healthy size portions

This is my to-go place in Arizona when I crave for Korean food. I lived in Korea for a while and trust me this is THE place if you want to have authentic Korean food. Delicious food and a very friendly atmosphere. Highly recommend this place.

One of my favorite korean eatery. Have tried a variety of their tofu soup and love them all, the broth is very flavorful. Also tried several other dishes here (seafood noodle soup, japchae, bulgogi, bibimbap, seafood pancake, etc) and have always been satisfied with their flavor and portion size. 

However, their side dishes are not as good as Gogi's. I also like the taste of Gogi's kimchi  better than Chodang's. Prices are a little higher than other korean restaurants in town. 

Would be nice if they offer lunch special like Gogi.

Ate here the other night with the hubs. We both loved it! We shared the seafood tofu soup and dolsot bibimbop. I was reluctant to try the seafood tofu soup (as I don't always trust AZ seafood) but decided to live life on the edge and went for it! So glad I did because it was amazing and spicy; none of that wimp spice too many places serve up. Just beware that parking is limited, but it wasn't too busy when I went so no problem there!

this place has been around as far back as i can remember and as a matter of fact there aren't to many Korean places around they are now starting to open up all around the valley. this place runs a tight crew they don't waste any time in getting you seated and served. i just love their menu because there is a lot to choose from anything from soups to dumplings to noodles and rice, they have it all here. you get a lot of food for your buck and i can guarantee you that you will leave there satisfied.

Can't wait to return and try more of the menu. I had the Korean marinated bbq and it was delish. I went in during lunch and was so happy with the portions- it was perfect. Not too much but I was full when I left. Rice was perfectly sticky. The sides we yummy too. There was some kind of Apple salad type dish I've never had before for a side and it was almost like dessert. Glad to know this place is down the street from my home . I will definitely be back
Been here about 5 times now and its consistently great food and service. Crave it everyday.

I love this place.... I have to say it's always in my top 2 choices of Korean restaurants . I love the staff they are quick and great. The food is always on point. I have never been upset with anything I have ordered from here. Side dishes are always perfect too!

The Tofu Soup is amazing.. that alone carries this restaurant to the four stars.  If you love food as much as i do, it will help you overlook the extremely overbearing AC vents that sometimes pound down upon you all year long, or the service that is catered towards the more "ethnic" (cough korean cough) patrons.  example : i walked in with my party, and they told me to wait because they have to clean some tables, a group of ethnic individuals walked in.. waited behind us for a little bit, then walked over and spoke in korean to the other staff member and were sat down before us.  so yeah.. i was upset but did not mind after i had the taste of their yummy soup again.

Not the best quality of Korean food I've had in the area. However, this place has the best service out of all the Korean restaurants I've been to and that speaks volumes. Additionally, they have the best and most consistent side dishes compared to other Korean places in Arizona. The outside may not look like much, but the inside is definitely inviting with their comfortable decor and atmosphere.
I'm finally reviewing Chodang - my favorite Korean restaurant :) I can never get enough seafood tofu soup and galbi, but our stomachs are always bursting when we leave!

Perfectly acceptable Korean food.  

We've been pretty disappointed with most of the Korean food around town, which has ranged from mediocre and expensive (Hodori) to awful and expensive (Red Kimchi/Korean Restaurant) to just generally mediocre (Takematsu).

Chodang was reasonably priced and not bad at all.  Make no mistake - this ain't LA's Koreatown - but it's the only place we've found that's at all acceptable.

We had six panchan to start which were decent if not inspired then a pretty big portion of galbi, a nice seafood soon dobu and a seafood pajeon.  The galbi was quite nice, the soon dobu was perfect and the pajeon was good, but a bit odd, more like a 2 inch thick frittata than a traditional pajeon.

About $50 for a big meal for three people. Service was friendly and quick.

Decided to come here after craving something warm for the cold weather.  We have been to a few other korean places where I was disappointed in the tofu and bbq.  This place is as good as it gets for korean tofu in AZ! We got a soon tofu and spicy pork.  

Pan chan (sides)- Yummy kimchi and potatoes 
Seafood&beef tofu-  Amazing flavor and lots of clams!! 
Spicy pork-  So flavorful and amazing ! 

Come here for the best korean food in the east valley! I'm pretty sure I will soon become a regular even though its quite a drive.

This restaurant in a scary part of town is really great. My go to dish is usually a tofu soup or dolsot bibimbap. They are excellent. My only reason for downgrading from 5 stars is that they will not add the raw egg to your boiling tofu soup and have a little notice on the top of their menu about it. The banchan here are very good. They have kalbi and bulgogi but it is not grill your own. I have seen many koreans in this restaurant and that is always a good sign.

I haven't ever had the BBQ meats here because the other Korean dishes Chodang offers are really good.  The ba bim bop is has really fresh ingredients and comes in a normal temp dish or a stone pot.  I recommend getting the one that comes in the stone pot.  

I normally eat the spicy pork soup or tofu soup and both of these dishes are offered in a varying degree of spicy between 1 and 5.  They're supposed to be served relatively spicy so go with a 3 or higher if you can handle it.  Also he soups come piping hot to your granite table and the server will ask if you want an egg added - if you're "ok" with eggs but not sure if it'll taste good with your soup- just say "yes".  Trust me.

The pun chun  (the small dishes of food they bring to you before the meal) is pretty good.  The kimchee is hit and miss but often times it tastes good.  The other dishes seem to vary depending on what they have available but for the most part it's all quite tasty.

I've only eaten here for dinner but I've eaten here often and know that the food is consistently good.  Everyone I've brought with me to this place loves it.  

Special note: Slow down and approach at an angle when you drive into the parking lot - it's kinda steep and bumpy.
The only place to go for Korean in the area.  If you can do the gangnam style dance, you get 20% off. :)

Way betta then thee Hodori 5 miles away.

They have good banchan (sides) as well as overall goodness with the usual Sundubu and Jaeyuk Bokkeum. (Pork Stir Fry)

I'd say Cafe Ga-Hyang and Chodang are the 2 best Korean restaurants in K-Restaurant Deprived Phoenix. ~ (Sadly the two best also demand a bit of a premium in terms of price point esp. compared to LA )

I hate giving Chodang 3 stars when I know I'm going to become a regular, but I've had truly outstanding Korean food in my lifetime in Seattle, San Jose, and Flushing and just can't pull 4 stars out of my hat this time.

The tofu soup was exactly right.  The Kalbi could have been a little more tender, but the flavor was perfect.  And I really enjoyed the generous side dishes.  I do hope they expand their menu to include more of the traditional Korean casseroles.

Still the very best Korean joint I can find. After going here for two years you think I would have completed a review. But I wanted to be the only white dude in this place! Then I found it won best soup in Phoenix Magazine! Oh no the secret is out! I wish the oyster soup would leave the menu or simply stop tempting me and not having it.

This is the place for Korean jjigae - spicy tofu soup in a little black cauldron.  Unlimited side dishes - I like the dried and pickled seaweed, the soy sauce Mung bean sprouts, the vinegar skinny radish kimchi, and the spicy regular kimchi (not the best, but one of the spiciest).  Most tofu soups here are around $10, and you're eating it to the sound of some 90's tunes.  But the hot tofu soup is the best.  I like the mushroom kind.  Not sure about the other dishes, but Chodang is a great place to go if you're near the 202 south or anywhere near Chandler Mall.

This is my second time visiting this place on a Saturday night. That being said, my service tonight was better than my first visit. Oh what a difference an hour makes. There are only 2 servers for this place on a Saturday night and they are busy, like crazy busy. The busyness is understandable given that the food here is amazing. 
I was greeted and seated promptly. I was given water and 6 little side dishes to snack on while waiting on my meal, they consisted of an apple salad, 2 types of kimchi, bean sprouts,  pickled daikon radish, seaweed paper and a spicy potato dish.  I ordered a number 21 Galbi which is served on a large platter with sliced onions underneath. First off, all the little sides were filled with flavor and each one different in taste and texture. The galbi was marinated and flame grilled perfectly. Not one piece came out burnt. Hands down, absolutely delicious. I also tried their Bohae which is a Korean black raspberry wine. It was a little too sweet for my everyday taste but it went with my meal perfectly. 
I would say that compared to places that allow you to cook at the table this place is better. The chefs in the kitchen know what they're doing!

If you are looking for authentic Korean food this is it. Chodang is one of, or even may be thee best, Korean BBQ places I have ever experienced. Their BBQ pork and beef tastes like it has been marinated for days, so delicious. Another awesome choice are their Babimbop bowls. Oh my goodness, you cannot go wrong because whatever you order will be absolutely delicious.

This is my go to place for authentic Korean food in the east valley. From the moment you walk in it smells, looks, and feels like I'm back in Korea. Everything I have tried has been amazing, and I'll definitely be back regularly for my hanguk shikdang fix.

It had been awhile since we had Korean food, so yesterday we headed over to Chodang. Had it not been for Yelp, I would not have known it was there. I'm glad to find it. 

It's a fairly small place compared to other restaurants like Takamatsu in Chandler, but not too small. Kinda cozy I guess. Anyway, we ordered the bulgogi dinner plate (about $14.00), the bulgogi lunch plate ($8.50) and bibimbap. They messed up our order a little though, and the bulgogi lunch plate ended up being kalbi, but that was okay. Actually, the kalbi was better than the bulgogi. The portions were a decent size, at least average with the dinner plate being above average. 

Other reviewers have said this is the best Korean food in Phoenix. I cannot agree with that. I have had better. However, this was pretty darn good. The bulgogi was about average, but the kalbi was very good. My wife also enjoyed the bibimbap. As is customary, they brought out the usual assortment of kim chi and other side dishes, and that was all great. We discovered that our 2 year old loves kim/nori! He ended up eating three servings of the stuff! 

Other than messing up our order, which was a blessing in disguise, the service was very good and friendly. Even though this is not the best Korean food in town, it was good enough. We'll be back.

The service is really fast. The prices are good. Tofu soups run around $9. The bipimbap and the bbq is a deal compared to other Korean places as it is around $11 and $13. The side dishes are good. I don't care for the apple mayo thing they got going on. Korean restaurants should stick with Korean side dishes. I love how their rice comes in stone pots.

Sad to say, I don't really understand the hype.  Maybe I just didn't get a dish that satisfied my Korean BBQ craving... I ordered the BBQ Bulgogi for $13.95 and thought it was A-OK. Additionally, the side dishes did not WOW me either. Kimchi wasn't as spicy or maybe it wasn't fermented too long? I did like how the sea weed wasn't too salty. Maybe next time if they throw anchovies and rice cake on their side dishes, I'd be impressed. I really wanted to like this place and recommend it as the #1 place in Az, but I just didn't have a overall satisfying feeling. I'll have to give this place another try and see if I feel the same way.

As you enter note the three kimchee earthen jars on display. That's what they used in the past to store kimchee in the cold ground during winter. This was before fridges especially for kimchee were made. 

Good Korean food as testified by my Korean friend whom I was with. It was great that they could adjust the heat of the soondubu (tofu stew) according to your tolerance level. The dolsot bibimbap was good too with enough sesame oil. When I'm next in town, I would be back.

This is definitely the best place in Phoenix. I have tried them all and keep coming back here. The servers are the sweetest girls in town, very generous with the side dishes and eager to make sure you are happy with your dining experience. I have tried most of their dishes and have never never had bad luck with any of them. They are tasty, hot, fresh and delicious. I highly recommend this restaurant to anyone who likes Korean food or is interested in trying it for the first time. It will be a good experience,  guaranteed!!!
Week day lunch specials 9.25 kalbi or bulgogi

Love the soup here. When you ask for spicy you get spicy. They crack a raw egg into the soup when they bring it out because the soups are served in clay pots which is still bubbling hot. You have the soup with a side of rice. This is usually all I need, because it's filling. My son loves the Korean spare ribs so he gets those and the fried dumplings which are ok. Definitely the spot if you feeling soup. I love the little trays of appetizers they bring out before your food. It consist of kimchi, seaweed, sweet potatoes, sweet apples, pickled bean sprouts and pickled some sort of root I think which is all good. 
The service is quick and they are on point even when the whole place is full.
tasty.  super delicious, local...what's not to like?  i've been back many times since.  it's chodang good.

I'm crying!  A little research on my reviews will show you my love from a place in my hometown in CA called lees tofu, and this place is the identical twin.  Right down to the menu.  I'm ordering the mushroom soon and the bulgogi.  If it's the same, even through my tears, I will just I love it.  If I update my review...it's to be mean.

I would say it's a decent place for Korean dishes. Can't find any disadvantages. If need to name one might be the price. It's a little bit higher than other Korean places. And the location is a little bit far and not that convenience compare to other places.

This place is super busy- which was a good sign for our first visit. We waited for about 30 minutes for a table which was okay, but there wasn't a designated waiting area so we were crammed over by the drink station. When we got to a table we realized we had NO IDEA what any of the food was, so we just took a stab in the dark and ordered a few different things off the menu. The mushroom tofu soup was absolutely amazing and I could eat it all day everyday forever. So. Good. I also had the tofu nuggets, which were good but boring. My husband had a meat dish which he seemed to enjoy very much. Definitely recommend- and you have to try the soup! We will be back after some further research into what the foods are so we walk in knowing what we want.

So far the best Korean Restaurant I have ever been in!! 
Food was great and service was great! 
Will definitely be a regular!
After going back to this place for a second try, the food and service was much better.  Portion size was great! Enjoy all the side dishes.
I highly recommend Chodang since it is one of the most authentic restaurants in the valley, recommend BBQ beef, cold noodles. You would love it for sure.

Bomb.com


If you like Korean you will be very impressed with this place.

Pretty much everything we had here was absolutely fantastic as well as the service. Do not let the outside for you. This is a very nice restaurant inside. 

Try the Dol Cet Bim Bim Bap with egg and a plate of spicy pork. Ask for the hot sauce and be prepared to enjoy the hell out of yourself.

Keep in mind these foods are all best when mixed together!!!

Great Korean in the valley of the sun! If you're looking for authentic Korean stews and BBQ Korean short ribs, this place is the place to be. I recommend the soon tofu soup with mixes seafood, so bomb!

Finally brought the Wife here for lunch. I had the Bulgogi Special. And wife had a Tofu Soup that she loved.. She is usually very picky when it comes to Asian cuisine. We will definitely be back. All the food we have tried so far has been consistent and Very good quality. Prices are a tad bit high, but well worth the quality of food. Each time I have been there, the service is great as well.

Definitely one if my favorite Korean restaurants in town. The galbi and kimchi tofu soup are awesome. I love their spicy pork dish as well. Service is not the best but just because they are always packed. You definitely get your moneys worth here.
Such friendly and fast service!  Food came piping hot and was bursting with flavor.  I was very happy with our visit.  Will definitely be back.

We are a fan of this place for lunch as it is way less pricier than dinner.

Love the little salad apps that come out before - the apple one is my favorite. Love the BBQ and bibimbop, flavorful and the egg is always cooked just right. The service can be really packed on a Friday lunch so get there early to avoid long food wait times. The good thing is there are quite a few asian folks that dine there so you know it's good!

A bit pricey but delicious Korean food. I enjoy the tofu soup. My family like the spicy chicken bulgogi but my boyfriend says it doesnt taste like much. Id go just for the soup tbh. Sides are good. Kimchi is not  spicy at all. The meats are good. Kalbi is one of my favorite dishes. I don't hate it here.
Great Korean food for the phoenix valley area.  We ordered BULGOGI and JAP CHAE.  The price was decent and the portion was huge.  Very clean and fast service.

Fresh, great quality ingredients. Each side dish had a distinct flavor. Although nothing was "vegetarian" on the menu, they were able to alter a few dishes to make them vegetarian. I truly enjoyed my stone pot bibimbap!
Really traditional Korean food :) Reminds me the Seafood Tofu soup I've had in Seoul.

[Right at about 3.5 stars for food and service.] 

Finding myself here as the first to join of group of Yelpers at their international supper, the restaurant was ready for the 15 or so that had said they were "IN" .  They were anxiously awaiting our arrival.  Slowly a few more wander in 6 in all.  They were ready, releaved yet slightly disapointed that more didn't show.  

I found the sides/banchan to be good and plentiful, the kimchee and the dakon radish were very good as was an apple salad that tasted much like a waldorf salad with a mayo dressing.  This was the first time I had been presented with roasted seaweed/nori at the table, which I enjoy. Ordering the Kalbi, I didn't stray far from what I love.  But I did try some of Lindsey's Bulgogi.  Quite tasty as well.  
The prices were comprable to Hoodori and I would have to say the atmosphere is about the same. Clean and simple cafe style.  

If your are looking for quality Korean fare...this is a worthy stop!

Pretty good place.. decided to come here a couple months ago after reading reviews from yelp for a long time now..  tofu soups are yummy.. galbi ribs were also pretty good.. kimchee was average.. jap chae was very well portioned.. overall a great experience..  a little pricey for lunch.. but I think al korean restaurants are overpriced.. guess that's my chinese side.. lol, will def be back?? Love the music!

I've heard great things about Chodang so we made the trip out to Chandler and celebrated my father's 70th birthday there.

We feasted for my pop's birthday.  For (4) people we ordered (2) servings of Kalbi, (1) Bulgogi, (1) Jap-Chae, (1) order of fried mandoo, and (1) kimchi Tofu soup.  

Of course it was too much food, but we really enjoyed all the flavors.  The banchan was great, and they replenished the side dishes as we ate them up.  

There is no cooking at the table here, but don't let that hold you back, they cook it perfectly in the kitchen :-)

The waitstaff was extremely friendly.  Never had to ask for a drink refill or any of the banchan to be replenished. 

We will definitely come back when in the area!

PS. No birthday treats/goodies we could purchase for my pops but that was no biggie.

I've tried a few Korean restaurants in Phoenix to answer that bulgogi crave. It's hard to find a match to what I've used to eat when I lived in Songtan, S. Korea, but this place comes close. I mean to try other dishes but can't steer away from their beef bulgogi with sam (lettuce for wrap). This one isn't the type that grill in front of you, but the taste and friendly service make up for it. I highly suggest for others to try. Well worth your money.

I am Korean and this place has authentic Korean dishes.  Not quite as good as food my mother used to make.   Since we moved here from Southern California I have been looking for good Korean restaurant. Only reason I gave 4 stars is the prices.  I think they are little high.
If you are a asian, you must try this restaurant. The tofu soup with seafood is so good! And there will be a long line if you get there too late

My wife and I finally had lunch at Chodang after having it on our list for quite sometime.  We ordered the Spicy BBQ Chicken and Seafood Tofu Soup.  Since we're new to Korean food, we didn't really know what to expect.  We enjoyed the side dishes that were served with our meal.  The Kim chi with the seaweed wrap was our favorite, but we enjoyed all of them.  In terms of our main course, the BBQ chicken was good, but the tofu soup was a little bland for me even after ordering it spicy.  Since this was my first time trying Korean food, I'm not sure if the tofu soup is supposed to be this way or not.  Nevertheless, the high quality of the food was apparent in all dishes, and we did enjoy our lunch.  

Service was very friendly and attentive.  They were eager to answer questions, provide drink refills, and check in on us at appropriate intervals.  They even offered refills on the side dishes.  Good overall experience.

One of my favorite Korean restaurants in the valley. I love the tofu soup  with Korean bbq lunch combos!! So good. I miss all the amazing spicy tofu and BBQ places in La and this restaurant comes very close. They have other really amazing dishes. The vegetable mixed noodle dish   is very good with large amounts of veggies mixed perfectly with the red bean paste and a little dash of sesame oil. Another favorite if I'm not eating the spicy tofu soup is the bulgogi jun gol ( ) which is bulgogi in a large pot with vegetables and noodles. So good especially on a cold day. Their food is my comfort food!!! My Korean food away from home. Also my favorite is the seafood pancake () as an appetizer. And lastly, my favorite if I'm craving rice is the dol dot bibimbap which is the stone pot mixed rice dish. Yum!!
This place was great! The service was really speedy, and all of the food was really tasty. We will definitely be returning!

This place is amazing, hidden spot along the main road there is parking along back of the front is full.  Greeted right away and sat immediately which was perfect.   First time here so our waiter went over everything and what his favorites were.  Also explained the Korean vodka on how people drink it and like it.  

The food came out fast and from first bite we were in love.  I ordered the Korean bbq rib plate and my fiancé got the spicy chicken. Both full of flavor in every bite meat and chicken cooked perfectly.  Plus it comes with 6 different side dishes and rice.  It's a win win all around at this place.  

Can't wait to come back for more

They make the best tofu soup in the valley!!!

Kalbi was really tasty as well. 

Service was always good.

I was complaining to a friend that since Takamatsu took a dump, I haven't been able to find another Korean BBQ and she told me about Chodang. I have been past this place a thousand times and never knew what it was.... I am so glad she recommended it because this place is awesome!!!! We tried it out today for lunch and it was perfect!!! Fast service, clean, friendly - just great!!! I had the Bulgogi lunch and my boss had the Bibimbap in the hot bowl and everything was delicious!!!
So happy to have found this place - We will be back :)

Showed up here to eat with about 10 co-workers.  Initial service was prompt with our order taken in about 2 mintues.  Drinks arrived shortly after.  I ordered the spicy pork dish which is accompanied by a small bowl of rice and the requisite Korean side dishes.  The pork was tasty, and a bit spicy, but on the fatty side.  The sides were mostly un-remarkable.  All in all, it was fun to try something new, but there was nothing here that I experienced that would bring me back.

I did read the other reviews that talked about the soups, so I might have to give it another shot ... so many places to try, so little time/money.

Great experience for lunch hour today! Was not very busy when we got there about 12pm. Sat down as soon as we walked in. Two servers that were very friendly and attentive. Food came quick and was piping hot. Ordered the beef tofu soup and kalbi. Portions were big and prices were great. Will definitely be back!

The food meets expectations but the portion is very French.  The banchans were very tasty and I loved the sweet apple with mayo.  I left hungry and refills of banchans were not offered.  I hoped they actually had combination meals but I had to order the soup separately which will set me back $25 for lunch which I am not exactly willing to do as many Korean restaurant in LA would be considered a norm.  That said, the presentations were excellent.

This place is absolutely one of my favorites in all of Phoenix! Been coming here for about 7 years and I've always had a wonderful experience each time. Very, very fast service (food usually comes out around 5 minutes after you order and its always hotter than you can eat right away,) friendly staff always trying to accommodate you, and just overall fantastic food. I can't say enough food things about this place. It's just so good. Stop reading and go right now.

My first yelp review should go to my all time favorite Korean restaurant in AZ. The food, service, and cleanliness at Chodang are amazing. Not only is the food delicious, authentic, & for a reasonable price (considering how much food you're getting), my favorite part is that they are not stingy with their side dishes. I'm sure I'm not the only one who is in love with side dishes, so when they offer more (once they see you've finished some), it makes the experience even better. 

I've been a regular there for about a year & have had the please of being served by different people; all of them were respectful & very attentive. 

Now for the food, my boyfriend & I enjoy the Tofu soups: favorites being mushroom, seafood & the bean paste soup (apparently it's an acquired taste).  I love love love the Nakji Dolsot Bibimbap (spicy octopus)- the octopus is always cooked well & it's spicy!

If I lived in AZ I would be a repeat offender for sure!
Thanks to YELP :) I found this amazing gem!
Came here for dinner otw to the airport to fly back to Las Vegas.
I ordered to bulgogi and kalbi!
I'm in love! Delicious!!!!
Would love to come back and try their tofu soup.
If you're in AZ and looking for fantastic Korean food! Chodang is worth the visit!
Good quality food, about $20 a person.
I'm a fan!
-Miss Yelp 2012

It's good, authentic Korean food. I had the BBQ pork.  Spicy, but in a good way. The place looks kinda sketchy from the outside.  Inside it's simple, but what matters is the food, and it delivers.  Will go back again.

Chodang serves the kind of food that you can only find in Los Angeles.  Not only is their food delicious, they're open 24/7!    The decor of the place is really nice and it's a nice clean place.  I recommend the tofu soup here but I would pass on the bibim bap. Despite being served in a hot stone bowl, the rice is pretty soggy and never crisps up. 

Definitely give this place a try if your on this side of town. 3.5 stars!

Great place! 

I've never really been a fan of trying new things. If I find something I like, I get it over and over and over. 

The girlfriends birthday came around and she told me that all she wanted was to try something different...so we went to Chodang. 

Different is definitely the word I would use, but in a good way. They start the meal by bringing out 6 small appetizers (we weren't sure what to do with them the first time we went there. do we put mix it with the food, do we eat it separately?) The entrees arrived promptly and were delicious. Service was excellent. We took my parents there a second time as well and they seemed to enjoy it as well. 

Anytime you're in the mood to try something a little different and alot tasty I would recommend Chodang.
Loved this place! Randomly found it while driving through Mesa and it's best authentic food I've found!

The food is delicious and the waiters are kind and caring. Coming from a traditional Korean family, I can say that their food is authentic. I think what matters most is the food such as the famous kimchi soon tofu, seafood, and traditional bulgogi and galbi. I recommend this place!
The bulgogi was really disappointing... not worth another visit back, especially given that Chandler has many Korean BBQ options.
This is the best Korean food in Phoenix, hands down.  I am a fan.  The Soondooboo is great, and the side dishes are wonderful.  This place gets busy so sometimes you have to be patient.

Wednesday lunch.Nice clean cafe.
Ordered a traditional Korean dish, bi bim bap.
Hot stone bowl with rice, and a variety of veggies and beef. Came with a bowl of beef broth. 6 sides on the table including Kim Chee and a pretty tasty sliced apple , to add to the bowl.
It was good, I enjoyed it, but I can't say I loved it. Nothing at all wrong with the food or service, just not my favorite. Strong dose of garlic, overpowering other flavors.
I've discovered I prefer other Asian styles and spices. 
Food must be pretty authentic, mostly Korean folks eating there.

This is one of our favorite places to eat here in Chandler.  Delicious, well-presented foods, great variety, awesome side dishes, and a quiet, well-lit dining room.  The portions are enormous, so plan to bring some home, or share a meal with someone.  My only complaint would be about the background music (Kenny G? Really?).
Awesomeness and delicious! Food is on authentic Korean and on point. Feels like a taste of home.

Food was good.  Service was pretty quick.  Place was busy when I got there around 1800 and got busier.  Not a lot of Korean restaurants around so if you looking for Korean food this would be a good choice.

My first visit to Chodang was just okay.

The waiter was eating his lunch in the dining room when we arrived.  He promptly got up and sat us.  To be fair, when we arrived it was at about 3:15 in the afternoon.  The dining room was completely empty except for us.  Our table had a couple crumbs on it, but looked like it had been recently wiped down.  The waiter placed paper placemats atop the table after seating us.  

Both my dining companion and I ordered the bibimbap.  When it was served, we were surprised that each of us only had approximately 1 tablespoon full of meat, perhaps less than one ounce in the entire dish.  The meat was also chilled, which was unexpected.

I've had bibimbap a handful of times and have loved it every time, except this one.  It was just okay for me.  When I added the hot sauce, it made it better tasting, albeit a little too hot since I squirted out a little too much.

I loved all the side dishes, though I did not try the dried seaweed.  

The bathroom did not have paper towels stocked, though there was a place for them.  There was only a hand dryer.  The wallpaper in the bathroom was peeling.  I think this bathroom needed some attention.

All in all, I was a little disappointed in Chodang.  I am giving it three stars only because the waiter was attentive.  I will not be returning to this establishment.

I've been here twice and I'll go again. Go with someone else and share dishes. That way you can try  more! I have had the tofu soup, the tofu mushroom and no. 72 and they were all so good. The small dishes they serve before your meal are all so good. Can't wait to go back and try more new dishes!

We come here often after having lived in Korea for over a year. 

I love the yu kei chong and the bulgogi. In wife gets dolsot and bipimbop. The Kimchi is excellent. They've got the Korean OB beer. 

Highly recommend.

Their Tofu soup is to die for. It is delicious and prices are affordable. However, their Korean BBQ beef and rib vary. There are times they are absolutely delicious, but there are days it was overcooked and tasteless. It is hit or miss with these two dishes. Nevertheless, Tofu soup is still very consistent and I will definitely recommend it. 

As far as service goes, it is excellent when business is slow, but they are ALWAYS short staffs during the weekend and/or weeknight. It is extremely hard to get their attention or refill. Several times, they completely forgot about what I wanted (a glass of water, refill, or napkins) because there are only 2 waiters/waitresses during those hours.

good service, but food was just mediocre. tried the seafood tofu soup, the yook gae jjang, and the dol sot bi bim bap. all were decent, but just nothing extraordinary. the "extra spicy" tofu soup was not spicy enough and the bi bim bap lacked in some of the traditional ingredients. side dishes were good, but once at this place was enough for me.

So, I kinda feel bad that I didn't try any of the tofu soups here, since that is their specialty, but I was craving bibimbap so bad, so that's what I got. I was kind of bummed that it Just didn't hit the spot for me (Insert emoji crying face) It had too much rice, which did not get crispy on the bottom of the bowl (which is normally the best part!) and was missing that good savory/sweet Korean bbq flavor on the meat. One thing I was happy with was that it came with a raw egg. Normally the bowl is so hot it quickly cooks the egg as you mix it all together. Since the bowl wasn't hot enough to crisp the rice, it took a little bit longer than usual to cook up the egg. With all that said, it wasn't horrible or anything, it just was t the bibimbap I was looking for. 

I would love to go back though, and try the tofu soups, as I mentioned, that is more their specialty. The service was great, and it's very clean and cute inside. Prices were good too and they have a nice selection of Korean beers. Next time I'm in town, I may try it again if I happen to be in the area.
